docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: DIVISION 14 POWERS OF COURTS (CORPORATIONS ACT PART 9.5) [r 14.1]

heading.title: DIVISION 14 POWERS OF COURTS (CORPORATIONS ACT PART 9.5) [r 14.1]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: DIVISION 14 POWERS OF COURTS (CORPORATIONS ACT PART 9.5) [r 14.1]

p.text: [Div 14 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,995] r 14.1 Appeal from act, omission or decision of administrator, receiver or liquidator, etc (Corporations Act s 554A, s 1321)

p.text: All appeals to the Court authorised by the Corporations Act must be commenced by an originating process, or interlocutory process, stating:
the act, omission or decision complained of; and
in the case of an appeal against a decision — whether the whole or part only and, if part only, which part of the decision is complained of; and
the grounds on which the complaint is based.
[subr (1) am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
Unless the Corporations Act or the Corporations Regulations otherwise provide, the originating process, or interlocutory process, must be filed within:
21 days after the date of the act, omission or decision appealed against; or
any further time allowed by the Court.
[subr (2) am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]

The Court may extend the time for filing the originating process, or interlocutory process, either before or after the time for filing expires and whether or not the application for extension is made before the time expires.

As soon as practicable after filing the originating process, or interlocutory process, and, in any case, at least 5 days before the date fixed for hearing, the person instituting the appeal must serve a copy of the originating process, or interlocutory process, and any supporting affidavit, on each person directly affected by the appeal.

As soon as practicable after being served with a copy of the originating process, or interlocutory process, and any supporting affidavit, a person whose act, omission or decision is being appealed against must file an affidavit:
stating the basis on which the act, omission or decision was done or made; and
annexing or exhibiting a copy of all relevant documents that have not been put in evidence by the person instituting the appeal.
[r 14.1 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]

level.toc-caption: [15,995.5] Appeal against rejection of proof of debt

p.text: Legislation cited in [15,995.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 1321.

heading.title: Appeal against rejection of proof of debt

p.text: An appeal by a person against a liquidator's rejection of a proof of debt is an application in the winding up. It should be made by interlocutory process in the winding up proceedings. The person appealing should be the applicant and the liquidator should be the respondent. The company itself is neither a necessary nor a proper party to the application: see Jones v Brien (1994) 13 ACLC 99; BC9403136 .

The court’s function under s 1321 is to determine the appeal and to “confirm, reverse or modify” the liquidator’s decision. The section does not distinguish between different types of decisions. It is available as a means of reviewing the exercise of a liquidator’s discretion or a decision on a matter of business judgment. In cases of that kind, the court’s main concern is to see whether the liquidator acted unreasonably or in bad faith: Frontier Touring Co Pty Ltd v Rodgers (as liquidator of Kidz.net Services Pty Ltd) (2005) 223 ALR 433; [2005] NSWSC 668; BC200504878 at [2] per Barrett J; Re Bridgeport — Advisers & Asset Managers Pty Ltd (2005) 221 ALR 146; [2005] NSWSC 757; BC200505700 at [59] per Barrett J (citing Hodgson J in Yeomans v Walker (1986) 5 NSWLR 378 at 383; 10 ACLR 753 ). But in cases of challenge with respect to a decision regarding a proof of debt, the proceedings though referred to as an ‘appeal’ from the liquidator’s decision are originating proceedings which the court hears de novo: Frontier Touring Co Pty Ltd v Rodgers (as liquidator of Kidz.net Services Pty Ltd) (2005) 223 ALR 433; [2005] NSWSC 668; BC200504878 at [2] per Barrett J citing (Tanning Research Laboratories Inc v O’Brien (1990) 169 CLR 332 at 340–341; 91 ALR 180; BC9002954 ); Ilhan v Cvitanovic [2009] NSWSC 479; BC200905102 at [9] per White J (affidavits read on the appeal which were not before the liquidator).

The creditor’s claim in the appeal must broadly correspond with the claim originally sought to be conveyed by the proof of debt. It is not necessary that the creditor adhere to the precise basis on which the claim was originally propounded: Johnston v McGrath (2008) 67 ACSR 169; [2008] NSWSC 639; BC200804866 at [24]–[28] per Barrett J (allegations of knowledge and reliance in misleading conduct claims abandoned); Wabbits Pty Ltd v Godfrey [2009] NSWSC 1299; BC200910729 at [18]–[19] per Ward J (defective work claim abandoned).

A liquidator who defends a decision to reject a proof of debt is no longer acting in a quasi-judicial capacity; the liquidator is cast in the role of an adversary, defending the assets available for distribution against a liability which, according to the view he or she formed when acting quasi-judicially, is not legally enforceable. The liquidator may defend those assets against the creditor’s claim on any ground on which the company might have defended the claim had it been sued by the creditor. If the liquidator relies on those special defences which allow him or her to go behind a judgment, an account stated, a covenant or an estoppel in order to ascertain the true liability of the company, he or she is none the less in the role of an adversary, though the liquidator is required to act fairly in conducting the litigation. The issue in the proceeding is whether the liability referred to in the proof of debt is a true liability of the company enforceable against it: Frontier Touring Co Pty Ltd v Rodgers (as liquidator of Kidz.net Services Pty Ltd) (2005) 223 ALR 433; [2005] NSWSC 668; BC200504878 at [2] per Barrett J.
Legislation cited in [15,995.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 1321.

The expression “person aggrieved” (within s 1321 Corporations Act 2001) aims to do no more than distinguish a mere busybody from a person with a recognisable interest: Re Bridgeport — Advisers & Asset Managers Pty Ltd (2005) 221 ALR 146; [2005] NSWSC 757; BC200505700 at [61] per Barrett J. Where the complaint is as to deferral of consideration of a claim or inaction in response to a claim, the claimant is a “person aggrieved”: Re Bridgeport — Advisers & Asset Managers Pty Ltd, above, at [61] per Barrett J
Legislation cited in [15,995.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Regulations 2001 reg 5.6.51.

Corporations Regulations 2001 reg 5.6.51 provides that a creditor must bear the cost of proving their debt or claim unless the Court otherwise orders. The Regulations do not deal with costs on appeal against rejection of a proof of debt.

heading.title: Claims by the company or liquidator

p.text: If proceedings are brought by a company in liquidation, with the liquidator not being a party, and if those proceedings are unsuccessful, an order for costs will generally be made against the company but not against the liquidator, unless the liquidator has acted unreasonably: Mead v Watson (2005) 23 ACLC 718; [2005] NSWCA 133 at 23; BC200502533 . However, a defendant to such proceedings may be able to obtain, in advance of the hearing, an order for security for costs: Hession v Century21 South Pacific Ltd (in liq) (1992) 28 NSWLR 120 . If proceedings are brought by a liquidator in relation to a company’s affairs, generally an order for security for costs will not be made; but if those proceedings are unsuccessful, then an order for costs will generally be made against the liquidator personally: Re Wilson Lovatt & Sons Ltd [1977] 1 All ER 274 at 285 . The liquidator would generally be entitled to an indemnity from the assets of the company, although that may be denied if the liquidator has acted unreasonably: Silvia v Brodyn Pty Ltd (2007) 25 ACLC 385; [2007] NSWCA 55; BC200702048 at [49]–[51] per Hodgson JA, Ipp and Basten JJA agreeing at [86]–[87] (decision by primary judge on costs altered) citing In Re Silver Valley Mines (1882) 21 Ch D 381 .

heading.title: Claims against the company or liquidator

p.text: If proceedings brought against the liquidator are successful, generally a costs order will be made in such a way that the liquidator does not incur any personal liability: Re Wilson Lovatt & Sons Ltd [1977] 1 All ER 274 at 285 ; Re Bonang Gold Mining Co Ltd (1893) 14 NSWLR (Eq) 262, Re Beuna Vista Motors Pty Ltd (in liq) [1971] 1 NSWLR 72 ; Irons v Merchant Capital Ltd (1994) 116 FLR 204 at 209–10; BC9403181 , and Kirwan v Cresvale Far East Ltd (in liq) (2002) 44 ACSR 21; [2002] NSWCA 395; BC200207448 ; Mendarma Pty Ltd (in liq) (No 2) (2007) 61 ACSR 601; [2007] NSWSC 99; BC200701685 per White J at [13]–[34] . The result indicated by this principle may be achieved by ordering that the company in liquidation pay the costs (if the company is also a defendant), or by ordering that the liquidator’s liability for costs be limited to the amount of assets of the company available for that purpose. If the liquidator has acted unreasonably in defending the litigation, the liquidator may be made personally liable: In Re Beddoe [1893] 1 Ch 547 ; Mead v Watson (2005) 23 ACLC 718; [2005] NSWCA 133 at 23; BC200502533 ; Re Network Welding Pty Ltd (in liq) (No 2) [2001] NSWSC 809; BC200105484 . Generally, the same principles apply to administrators as to liquidators: Kirwan v Cresvale Far East Ltd (in liq) : Silvia v Brodyn Pty Ltd (2007) 25 ACLC 385; [2007] NSWCA 55; BC200702048 at [52]–[55] per Hodgson JA, Ipp and Basten JJA agreeing at [86]–[87](decision by primary judge on costs altered).

There may be exceptional circumstances warranting both assessment on the indemnity basis and disentitlement of the liquidator to recoupment out of the assets of the company. However, so entrenched is the expectation of recoupment that something in the nature of (or closely approaching) impropriety or recklessness must be found: Frontier Touring Co Pty Ltd v Rodgers (as liquidator of Kidz.net Services Pty Ltd (in liq)) — Costs [2005] NSWSC 849; BC200506393 at [4] per Barrett J (citing Hypec Electronics Pty Ltd (in liq) v Mead (2004) 61 NSWLR 169; 185 FLR 76; [2004] NSWSC 731; BC200405114 ). Extravagance in the conduct of the litigation might possibly represent such a circumstance: Nicou v Ngan [2005] NSWSC 570; BC200504207 at [8] –[10] (a submission to this effect was noted in proceedings seeking removal of a liquidator but the question was not decided).

It is appropriate that the liquidator, whose decision is challenged and who may be made subject to orders, be joined in the proceedings (even if there is another party interested in supporting the decision of the liquidator who could be a proper party to the proceedings): Silvia v Brodyn Pty Ltd (2007) 25 ACLC 385; [2007] NSWCA 55 at [60]; BC200702048 per Hodgson JA, Ipp & Basten JJA agreeing at [86]–[87]).

Leave to appeal is required to appeal to the Court of Appeal in respect of a claim for less than $100,000 see SCA s 101(2)(r): Johnston v McGrath [2007] NSWCA 231; BC200707522 at [7] per Young CJ in Eq, Giles JA and Handley AJA agreeing at [1], [44] (leave to appeal refused).
